redFlagsCommon.flagsHeader: Trafficking Red Flags to look for:
redFlagsCommon.questionsIntro: Many victims of human trafficking, especially children, may not identify as victims or may not know what “trafficking” is. Instead of asking them if they are being trafficked, ask them:

examples.liz:
"My trafficking story started when I was six years old. From six to 18, my mom sold me to men in our community. When it came to my school life, it's where I excelled. School was the only safe place I had. I used to sleep in the library at school because it wasn't safe to sleep at home or I wasn't able to sleep because there were men in my bedroom at night.

Going to elementary and high school, I rode a school bus. I went to a local Catholic school and I actually had the same driver for the entire duration of my school career. I think he saw things that didn't quite add up and didn't make sense. My bruises, my scars, telling him that I was clumsy and that I fell off my bike. He had the opportunity to observe the comings and goings from my house. Who was there to put me on the bus in the morning and who was there to pick me up at night? I would just tell him, "Oh, my uncle's here," and get off the bus.

I think that one of the biggest assets that a school bus driver would have is the rapport that they can build with another human being who trusts them to get them from point A to point B, and to keep them safe while they do it. Building that rapport means treating them like a human being and noticing the normal details, and the not so normal. If it was a hundred degrees out, you would notice someone who came in with a turtleneck and long pants. And you would wonder, what are they hiding underneath the turtleneck? What is the reason for their clothing?

I truly believe that knowledge is what's going to make the difference. If you see something, you can say something. It's going to be that one small act that changes everything for a survivor. If the only thing you do is become trained and knowledgeable and understand that human trafficking even happens. So many people actually think it's a myth. I'm here to tell you that I lived it. I survived it, and no other human being should have to go through it."

- Survivor Leader Liz Williamson

redFlagsSchool.flags:
• Students who have begun to accumulate frequent absences.
  • A new or different person, likely older, dropping off or picking up a student from the bus stop or school; this person may demonstrate controlling behavior.
  • Signs of bruises, physical trauma, or malnourishment.
  • Inappropriate dress for the weather or school.
  • Symptoms of anger, panic, irritability, phobia, or hyperactivity that weren’t there before.
  • Mood swings, such as frequent crying, temper tantrums, or clingy behavior.
  • Markings or tattoos that could be a pimp’s branding.
  • Students who suddenly have the latest gadgets, new clothes, manicured nails, or other material possessions that a pimp may give them during a grooming process.
  • Any acknowledgement that the student has a pimp and/or is making a quota.
redFlagsSchool.intro:
Human trafficking is modern-day slavery. Traffickers use force, fraud and coercion to control their victims. Any minor engaged in commercial sex is a victim of human trafficking. Whether you are a school bus driver, aide, monitor, or office staff, members of the school transportation industry are in a position to spot potential human trafficking situations and save a life.

Trafficking can occur in many locations, including bus terminals, restaurants, hotels/motels, strip clubs, casinos, private homes, truck stops, rest stops, etc. We know that traffickers recruit victims out of schools, as well as online. We also know that child victims of trafficking will often continue attending school (and riding the school bus) even while they are being trafficked or groomed at night and on weekends.

Warning: Please do not approach traffickers. Allow law enforcement to deal with traffickers and recover victims. Approaching traffickers is not only dangerous for you and their victims but could lead to problems in the eventual prosecution of traffickers.
redFlagsSchool.post: If you are concerned about a child on your school bus, be sure to follow your school’s protocols on child trafficking or on reporting suspicions of abuse and neglect.
redFlagsSchool.postLink: If you haven’t seen the BOTL School Transportation Training Video you can view it at
redFlagsSchool.questions:
• Is anyone threatening you or making you do something you don’t want to do?
  • Is anyone controlling you, your money, or your belongings?
  • Do you feel safe with the person who picks you up or drops you off?
  • Is everything okay at home?
  • Have you ever sold sex for money or goods?

examples.california: Not long after the San Diego Metropolitan Transit System rolled out its anti-human trafficking program—which included the BOTL video—their transit security personnel made note of a man at one of their transit centers acting aggressively toward a young woman. When the same man later returned to the transit center and was seen approaching other young women, transit officers shared their suspicions and evidence with the San Diego Human Trafficking Task Force which coordinated with other law enforcement agencies in California. The investigation culminated in the arrest of the man at a motel near Los Angeles where he and an accomplice were holding a young woman against her will.
examples.newYork: A law enforcement officer in New York City was called to the scene by a bus driver who was concerned for the welfare of two teenage girls who were in a restricted area of the bus terminal. The girls, who looked dirty and disheveled, had been begging for a free trip to Pennsylvania and one of the girls supposedly offered one driver sex in exchange for a ride. After getting them some pizza and spending some time talking with the girls in his office, the officer learned that the girls were cousins and before they ended up on the street, they’d been living with and working for the one of the girl’s “boyfriend” and his mother—in a house that was used as a massage parlor in which they were forced to provide sexual services. When the girl confronted her pimp/”boyfriend” about another girl he’d started sleeping with, the mother kicked her and her cousin out, maintaining control of all of their money and belongings. The case was promptly referred for further investigation, and the officer got the girls to safety. Following the investigation, the mother and son trafficking team was arrested, and the other victims at the brothel, including several minors, were recovered.
examples.ohio: A Lakefront Lines bus driver in Ohio was approached by a young woman on his bus who told him that she was being held against her will and forced into prostitution by a male passenger on the same bus. The driver—who had recently completed the BOTL training—notified dispatch and the Lakefront Lines safety team immediately sprang into action and got law enforcement on the scene. As more details of their circumstances were revealed, the young woman was connected to resources and the alleged perpetrator was arrested.
examples.washington: One week after a transit agency in Washington State showed the BOTL training video at a monthly staff safety meeting, an emotionally distraught young woman came into their transit center. She had severe bruising on her face and abrasions all over her body. An employee approached the young woman to see if she needed help. The employee learned that she had just been released from the hospital after being beaten, raped and robbed. She revealed information that suggested she was a victim of sex trafficking. She didn’t know what city she was in, had no phone and no money. She’d come to the transit center to find transportation to a friend who she believed was safe. The employee helped her contact the friend and got her a bus ticket. The employee and colleagues then pooled the cash they had in their own wallets to make sure the young woman had some money with her as she traveled.

flags.1:
• Passengers who are not allowed to speak for themselves.
  • Passengers whose tickets or identification documents are being controlled by another person.
  • Acknowledgement of a Pimp or Making a Quota.
flags.2:
• Minors traveling without adult supervision.
  • Minors who do not know the person who is picking them up at their destination.
  • Passengers who have never met the person who purchased their ticket for them.
  • People with bruising, branding or signs of physical trauma.
flags.3:
• Passengers who look dirty and disheveled, or seem confused, panicked, or afraid.
  • Cars that are frequently at the terminal but no one gets out to board a bus.
  • People in the terminal who regularly approach people who look vulnerable, especially if they never board a bus.
flags.4: • Anyone who is offering to exchange sex for money or any other good or service.

redFlagsTransit.intro:
Human trafficking is modern-day slavery. Traffickers use force, fraud and coercion to control their victims. Any minor engaged in commercial sex is a victim of human trafficking. Whether you work behind a ticket counter or as transit security, conduct bus maintenance, or are a professional driver, members of the bus industry are in a position to spot potential human trafficking situations and save a life.

Trafficking can occur in many locations, including bus terminals, restaurants, hotels/motels, strip clubs, casinos, private homes, truck stops, rest stops, etc. Traffickers recruit victims online and at various physical locations, including at bus stops, bus stations and in schools. Traffickers have been reported to utilize buses in transporting their victims during their exploitation. And, when victims are able to get out, a bus or bus terminal may be the first place they’ll go to find safety or escape.

Warning: Please do not approach traffickers. Allow law enforcement to deal with traffickers and recover victims. Approaching traffickers is not only dangerous for you and their victims but could lead to problems in the eventual prosecution of traffickers.

redFlagsTransit.questions:
• Do you feel safe with the person you’re traveling with?
  • Is anyone hurting you?
  • Are you free to come and go as you want?
  • Do you know the person who is picking you up?
  • Do your parents/siblings/relatives know where you are? If not, why not?
  • Are you or your family being threatened? In what ways?

report.intro:
Immediately: If you’re watching a crime in progress, call 911 and then call the hotline. If you are a school bus driver and concerned about a student, be sure to follow your school’s protocols on reporting suspected child trafficking or suspicions of abuse.

Anti-trafficking hotline advocates are available 24/7 to take reports of potential human trafficking. All reports are confidential, and you may remain anonymous. Interpreters are available. The information you provide will be reviewed by the National Hotline and forwarded to specialized law enforcement and/or service providers where appropriate.

about.intro:
Busing on the Lookout (BOTL) is a program of Truckers Against Trafficking (TAT), a 501(c)3 organization that exists to educate, equip, empower and mobilize members of the trucking, bus and energy industries to combat human trafficking.

Our three goals are:

  • Saturate the bus industry with BOTL materials.
  • Partner with law enforcement and government agencies to facilitate the investigation of human trafficking.
  • Marshal the resources of our partners to combat this crime.

resources.intro: Use the resources below to learn more about trafficking and how you can get involved.

laws.bullets:
• There is a lifetime ban on a CDL for any individual who uses their CMV in committing a felony involving a severe form of human trafficking.
  • All 50 states and DC have a law criminalizing sex trafficking.
  • 31 states have a buyer-applicable trafficking law that prohibits a mistake-of-age defense in prosecutions for buying a commercial sex act with any minor under 18.
  • Some states punish sex purchasers the same as traffickers, generally with felony-level crimes.
  • Washington identifies anyone who purchases a sexually explicit act as a human trafficker guilty of a Class A felony.
laws.intro2: Human trafficking is the recruitment, transportation, transfer, harboring or obtaining of persons through force, fraud and coercion for the purpose of exploitation.
laws.linkText: Learn more about the human trafficking laws in the US.
laws.title: @:resources.btns.humanTraffickingLaws

drivingFreedom.description:
Welcome to Driving Freedom, a TAT Podcast! As TAT works to educate, equip, empower and mobilize members of the truck, bus and energy industries to combat human trafficking as part of their regular jobs, we wanted to create a podcast that would serve as a helpful training tool to one of the largest mobile armies of eyes and ears out there on the roads seeking to recognize and report this heinous crime. Each short episode is designed to refresh critical issues learned and keep this life-saving information
top of mind.
drivingFreedom.title: Driving Freedom

video1.description: Hear from law enforcement, a trafficking survivor, and members of the bus industry—commercial, transit, and school—about the role the industry can play in combating human trafficking.
video1.title: BOTL Training Video

video2.description: BOTL’s free industry-specific training materials for casinos are designed to train gaming industry employees on how to recognize and report signs of human trafficking they may be seeing in the course of their everyday jobs. As buses carry patrons to and from casinos, those drivers may be coming into contact with trafficking victims who are being transported on those buses or see the bus as a lifeline for escape.
video2.title: Casino Webinar

video3.description: Truckers Against Trafficking presents this training on human trafficking and information on how law enforcement can investigate and prosecute this crime.
video3.title: TAT Law Enforcement Training

video4.description: Millions of children ride the school bus every day. For some of them, school is the only safe place they have. The BOTL School Transportation Training video describes the warning signs school bus drivers should be on the lookout for, outlines steps they can take if they suspect trafficking, and includes testimony from a survivor of child trafficking.
video4.title: BOTL School Transportation Training Video
